title: Understanding Vaginal Cancer
subtitle: What it is, why it's done, and what to expect

content.value: Vaginal cancer is a rare cancer that starts in the tissues of the vagina — the canal that connects the cervix to the outside of the body. Some cases develop from pre-cancerous changes called **VAIN (Vaginal Intraepithelial Neoplasia)**, where abnormal cells are present in the lining of the vagina.

items.title: Quick Facts
items.description: Quick Facts: Vaginal cancer is uncommon and is more often diagnosed in women over 60. Many cases are linked to high-risk HPV infection, and it can develop from pre-cancerous vaginal cell changes (VAIN). Early stages may cause few or no symptoms.

items.title: Remember
items.description: Vaginal cancer is rare, but symptoms should not be ignored. Unusual bleeding, persistent pelvic pain, discharge, or a lump inside the vagina should be checked by a doctor. Early assessment is important, as diagnosis at an earlier stage is linked with better treatment outcomes.

content.value: Vaginal cancer starts in the cells lining the vagina. Some cases develop from pre-cancerous changes called **VAIN (Vaginal Intraepithelial Neoplasia)**. Understanding this process helps with early detection.

items.title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma (most common)
items.description: Forms in the flat cells lining the vagina. It can develop from VAIN.

items.title: Adenocarcinoma
items.description: Develops from glandular cells within the vaginal lining and is less common.

items.title: Sarcoma of the vagina (a soft tissue cancer)

content.title: When to Contact Your Doctor
content.description: Seek medical advice if you experience unusual bleeding, persistent discharge, pelvic pain, pain during sex, or notice a lump inside the vagina. Early assessment is important, as diagnosis at an earlier stage is linked with better outcomes.

content.value: Common factors that may increase the risk.

steps: History of cervical cancer or cervical pre-cancer

content.title: Good to Know
content.description: These factors increase risk but do not mean you will develop vaginal cancer. HPV vaccination helps reduce the risk of HPV-related disease. There is no routine screening programme for vaginal cancer, so any persistent vaginal symptoms or known pre-cancerous changes should be checked by a healthcare professional.

content.value: Early vaginal cancer may not cause symptoms. As the condition progresses, signs can include:

items: Unusual vaginal bleeding (such as after sex or after menopause)
A lump or mass inside the vagina
Pain during urination or frequent urination
Changes in bowel habits, such as constipation

content.title: Vaginal Cancer Awareness
content.description: There is no routine screening programme for vaginal cancer. Pelvic examinations are important if you have symptoms or risk factors, as early assessment of unusual changes can support earlier diagnosis.

content.value: Vaginal cancer is usually investigated after symptoms or abnormal findings on examination. The diagnostic process may include:

steps: Pelvic examination – Inspection of the vulva and vagina using a speculum
Cervical screening test (if due) – May occasionally detect abnormal vaginal cells, but it is not a screening test for vaginal cancer
Vaginoscopy (colposcopy of the vagina) – A magnified examination of the vaginal lining
Biopsy – Removal of a small tissue sample to confirm whether cancer cells are present

content.title: Purpose
content.description: These tests help confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment planning.

content.value: Treatment depends on the cancer type, stage, location, and your overall health.

Surgery may be used in some early-stage cancers and may involve removing part of the vagina. Lymph nodes may be assessed depending on the situation. Reconstructive surgery may be considered in selected cases.

items.title: Radiotherapy
items.description: Often a main treatment for vaginal cancer

items.title: Chemoradiation
items.description: Chemotherapy given with radiotherapy in certain cases

items.title: Chemotherapy alone
items.description: Sometimes used in advanced or recurrent disease

content.value: Steps to reduce the risk of vaginal cancer and detect problems early.

items.title: Ways to Reduce Risk
items.description: HPV vaccination, Not smoking, Seeking medical advice for persistent vaginal symptoms, Early treatment of VAIN or cervical pre-cancers, Practising safer sex to reduce HPV exposure, Monitoring abnormal bleeding or discharge

items.title: Why It Matters
items.description: Early assessment of symptoms is important, as earlier diagnosis is linked with better treatment outcomes.

content.title: Take Action
content.description: Protect your health by getting vaccinated, avoiding smoking, and reporting unusual symptoms promptly. These steps help reduce the risk of HPV-related disease and support early detection.

content.value: Important points to remember about Vaginal Cancer

content.title: What You Should Know
content.description: Vaginal cancer is rare but can be serious. Awareness of symptoms—such as abnormal bleeding, unusual discharge, or pelvic pain—is important, as earlier diagnosis is linked with better treatment outcomes.

items.text: Early assessment of symptoms is associated with more effective treatment
Report unusual bleeding, discharge, or pelvic pain promptly
Medical check-ups are important if you have symptoms or known risk factors
HPV vaccination helps reduce the risk of HPV-related vaginal disease
Being aware of changes supports early detection

content.title: Final Message
content.description: Staying alert to symptoms and seeking medical advice early if changes occur are key steps in protecting your health.
